messages: 6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (15:03): the HTMLElement  attribute <-> content attribute mapping is just strange

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:03): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I think the interesting thing from http://www.w3.org/2010/02/rdfa/meetings/2011-06-09 is that all their discussion starts "lets assume a person that wants to use RDFa‚Ä¶"
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (15:03): but nothing new in HTML spec

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:04): That suggests they won't be very successful in reexamining earlier ideas about simplification because their mental model is "lets assume that most users are just like me"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:05): Anything in particular, 6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf, or just in general?
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (15:07): in general.
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (15:08): Setting element.contextMenu may magically set element's content attribute
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:08): What does ‚ÄúISO 10646 characters U+00A0 and higher‚Äù mean exactly? Characters in the range \u000 ‚Äì \uFFFF, or is that too limited?
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (15:09): yet if the menu element is removed from DOM, the content attribute still has its ID as value
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:09): (Read that in the CSS spec ‚Äî just asking here first.)
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (15:11): The spec really needs more reviewing
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:12): but what would you guys consider the upper limit if that‚Äôs all the spec says?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:13): I can't say for sure without reading it, but I would parse "ISO 10646 characters" to include code points above \uFFFF too
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:19): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: If you feel like reading: http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/syndata.html#value-def-identifier

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:23): Yeah, I would say this confirms it: "the backslash is followed by at most six hexadecimal digits (0..9A..F), which stand for the ISO 10646 ([ISO10646]) character with that number"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:23): "If the number is outside the range allowed by Unicode (e.g., "\110000" is above the maximum 10FFFF allowed in current Unicode)"
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:24): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Thanks! I should‚Äôve kept reading, I guess.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yeah. assuming that Web authors want to use RDFa (or Microdata for that matter) is FAIL
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:45): Web authors don't care about your metadata framework
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): they care about their client's marketing dept requiring Facebook Like buttons
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): or doing SEO
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:50): finds out about w3schools Online Certification Program
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:50): $95 per certificate
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:50): that's so sad

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (16:07): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: what‚Äôs sad is w3schools showing in the top of results when their info is often so crap (ref http://w3fools.com/ ), and the perception that they‚Äôre good or even _official_ among new coders b/c of the w3
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:08): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: yeah. I wonder how many bug reporting systems could use a "Please read http://w3fools.com/ before filing bugs." message
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (16:10): har! to be fair, they‚Äôve fixed some of those, but still it‚Äôs pretty atrocious. The guy is def. in it solely for the ad revenue
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:10): I wonder when we are going to see the first meta or rel keyword registration that puts a w3schools URL in the spec column

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (16:10): sad when things like MDC are better and lower in the result list
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (16:11): ohrly? heh, family enterprise eh

0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a (16:21): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: that's a very good question, i actually don't know
0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a (16:21): who has "claim" to html - whatwg or w3c?
0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a (16:22): imho it's an internet standard and belongs to the global general public, not to anyone
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:22): 0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a: I think the power game is detrimental
0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a (16:23): i mean c'mon, can't we just kiss and make up, seriously
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:23): HTML5 happened because reality didn't listen to the claims of ownership
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:23): 0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a: as I see it, part of the revert requests and issues are attempts to demonstrate some kind of W3C process power
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:23): (how dare anyone write anything about accessibility without consulting the WAI?)
0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a (16:23): this is where company / individual agenda starts to negatively affect the state of human being :)
0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a (16:24): the w3c is still the same as always - it's a bureaucracy

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:24): 0a516289150443ca820643c0ea289e3a: and then Hixie refuses to apply even trivial changes to the WHATWG copy--presumably in order to avoid giving in to the power demonstration of steve et al. and to avoid going on a slippery slope to more and more compromise
